member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.Ftp.FtpDataStream
member.summary: An FTP connection has got two streams, one for sending control commands an another one for "data" retrieval and "sending" This stream is the Control Stream of the FTP connection, meaning it will be used to transmit control commands and also for checking if transmissions of those control commands was ok.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.Ftp.FtpStream
member.summary: Summary description for FtpStream.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.Ftp.FtpCommandType
member.summary: Summary description for FtpMethod.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus
member.summary:
Specifies the operational state of a network interface.
New in v1.3

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Dormant
member.summary: The network interface is not in a condition to transmit data packets; it is waiting for an external event.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Down
member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.LowerLayerDown
member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets because it runs on top of one or more other interfaces, and at least one of these "lower layer" interfaces is down.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.NotPresent
member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets because of a missing component, typically a hardware component.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Testing
member.summary: The network interface is running tests.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Unknown
member.summary: The network interface status is not known.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Up
member.summary: The network interface is up; it can transmit data packets.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPInterfaceProperties
member.summary:
Provides information about network interfaces that support Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) or Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6).
New in v1.3

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPInterfaceProperties.GetIPInterfaceStatistics
member.summary: Provides Internet Protocol (IP) statistical data for the network interface.
member.returns: An object that provides traffic statistics for this network interface.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.InterfaceType
member.summary:
Specifies types of network interfaces.
New in v1.3

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceNotificationArgs
member.summary: DeviceNotificationArgs passed to interested parties when a device notification is fired. Contains the device class GUID, a flag indicating whether the device is attached or detached, and the device name.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceNotificationArgs.DeviceInterfaceGUID
member.summary: GUID of the interface/type/class of the device being attached or detached.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceNotificationArgs.DeviceAttached
member.summary: True if, after the latest event, the device is connected; false, otherwise.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceNotificationArgs.DeviceName
member.summary: The device name being attached/detached. Might be a stream driver name like COM1:, or something more descriptive like Power Manager, depending on the GUID.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceNotificationArgs.#ctor(OpenNETCF.GuidEx,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor for notification arguments.
member.param: Device class GUID
Device attached, true or false
Device name

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor
member.summary: Class for receiving device notifications of all sorts (storage card insertions/removals, etc.) When a change is detected, an event is fired to all interested parties. The parameters of the event indicate the GUID of the device interface that changed, whether the device is now connected or disconnected from the system, and the name of the device (COM1:, for example), which changed.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.#ctor(OpenNETCF.GuidEx,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructor for DeviceStatusMonitor. Specifies the class of notifications desired and whether notifications should be fired for already-attached devices.
member.param: GUID of device class to monitor (or empty to monitor *all* device notifications).

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.Finalize
member.summary: Destructor stops status monitoring.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.StartStatusMonitoring
member.summary: Initiates a worker thread to listen for reports of device changes. Listeners can register for notification of these changes, which the thread will send.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.StopStatusMonitoring
member.summary: Stops the worker thread which monitors for changes of status of the adapter. This must be done, if monitoring has been started, before the object is destroyed.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.OnDeviceNotification(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Raises the DeviceNotification event.
member.param: An EventArgs that contains the event data.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.BLOCK_DRIVER_GUID
member.summary: Fired when the block driver for a Storage Manager device is loaded.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.STORE_MOUNT_GUID
member.summary: Fired when the store, managed by the Storage Manager is ready.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.FATFS_MOUNT_GUID
member.summary: Fired when a FAT filesystem is loaded for a device.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.CDFS_MOUNT_GUID
member.summary: Fired when a CDFS filesystem is loaded.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.UDFS_MOUNT_GUID
member.summary: Fired when a UDFS filesystem is loaded.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.CDDA_MOUNT_GUID
member.summary: Fired when a CDDA filesystem is loaded.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.Active
member.summary: The Active property is true when the status is being monitored. If status monitoring is not occurring, Active is false.

member.name: E:OpenNETCF.Net.DeviceStatusMonitor.DeviceNotification
member.summary: Event fired when some aspect of the device's connected status has changed.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingOptions
member.summary: Used to control how Ping data packets are transmitted.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the PingOptions class.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingOptions.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the PingOptions class and sets the Time to Live and fragmentation values.
member.param: Specifies the number of times the Ping data packets can be forwarded.
True to prevent data sent to the remote host from being fragmented; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingOptions.Ttl
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of routing nodes that can forward the Ping data before it is discarded.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingOptions.DontFragment
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that controls fragmentation of the data sent to the remote host.

member.summary: Specifies the number of incoming packets that were discarded even though they did not have errors.

member.summary: Specifies the number of incoming packets that were discarded because of errors.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.MibIfRow.InUnknownProtos
member.summary: Specifies the number of incoming packets that were discarded because the protocol was unknown.

member.summary: Specifies the number of octets of data sent through this interface.

member.summary: Specifies the number of unicast packets sent through this interface.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.MibIfRow.OutNUcastPkts
member.summary: Specifies the number of non-unicast packets sent through this interface. This includes broadcast and multicast packets.

member.summary: Specifies the number of outgoing packets that were discarded even though they did not have errors.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType
member.summary: The NdisNotificationType enumeration defines the types of notifications which can be requested from NDIS.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisResetStart
member.summary: NdisResetStart is set when an adapter is being reset.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisResetEnd
member.summary: NdisResetEnd is sent when the reset process on an adapter is complete and the adapter is ready to be rebound.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisMediaConnect
member.summary: NdisMediaConnect is set when the communications media, an Ethernet cable for example, is connected to the adapter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisMediaDisconnect
member.summary: NdisMediaDisconnect is set when the communciations media, an Ethernet cable for example, is disconnected from the adapter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisBind
member.summary: NdisBind is set when one or more protocols, TCP/IP typically, is bound to the adapter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisUnbind
member.summary: NdisUnbind is set when the adapter is unbound from one or more protocols.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NdisNotificationType.NdisMediaSpecific
member.summary: NdisMediaSpecific is set when some notification not generally defined for all adapter types occurred.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor
member.summary: Class giving the ability to monitor NDIS adapters for changes in their state. When a change is detected, an event is fired to all interested parties. The parameters of the event indicate the type of status change and the name of the adapter which changed.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor.StartStatusMonitoring
member.summary: Initiates a worker thread to listen for NDIS-reported changes to the status of the adapter. Listeners can register for notification of these changes, which the thread will send.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor.StopStatusMonitoring
member.summary: Stops the worker thread which monitors for changes of status of the adapter. This must be done, if monitoring has been started, before the object is destroyed.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor.OnAdapterNotification(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Raises the AdapterNotification event.
member.param: An EventArgs that contains the event data.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor.Active
member.summary: The Active property is true when the status is being monitored. If status monitoring is not occurring, Active is false.

member.name: E:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterStatusMonitor.AdapterNotification
member.summary: Event fired when some aspect of the adapter's configuration or state has changed.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions
member.summary: The ip_option_information structure describes the options to be included in the header of an IP packet. The TTL, TOS, and Flags values are carried in specific fields in the header. The OptionsData bytes are carried in the options area following the standard IP header. With the exception of source route options, this data must be in the format to be transmitted on the wire as specified in RFC 791. A source route option should contain the full route - first hop thru final destination - in the route data. The first hop will be pulled out of the data and the option will be reformatted accordingly. Otherwise, the route option should be formatted as specified in RFC 791.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions.ttl
member.summary: Time To Live.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions.tos
member.summary: Type Of Service.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions.flags
member.summary: IP header flags.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions.optionsSize
member.summary: Size in bytes of options data.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType
member.summary: The StrengthType enumeration provides a list of relative RF Ethernet signal strength values that correspond to the strengths displayed by Windows CE itself.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.NotAWirelessAdapter
member.summary: The adapter for which signal strength was requested is not a wireless network adapter or does not report its signal strength in the standard way

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.NoSignal
member.summary: The adapter is not receiving a network signal

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.VeryLow
member.summary: The network signal has very low strength

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.Low
member.summary: The network signal has low strength

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.Good
member.summary: The network signal is good

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.VeryGood
member.summary: The network signal is very good

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthType.Excellent
member.summary: The network signal is excellent

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.SignalStrength
member.summary: The SignalStrength class provides a repository for the signal strength indication from an RF Ethernet network adapter. From an instance of this class, you can get the signal strength in dB, an enumerated value of type StrengthType indicating the relative strength, or a string representing the relative strength.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.SignalStrength.DBToStrength(System.Int32)
member.summary: The DBToStrength static conversion function can be used to take a dB strength value previously retrieved and generate a StrengthType enumeration value based on the relative strength.
member.param: Signal strength in dB
member.returns: StrengthType indicating strength that db parameter represents

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.SignalStrength.DBToString(System.Int32)
member.summary: The DBToString static conversion function allows a signal strength value in dB previously retrieved to be converted into the string representation of its relative signal strength.
member.param: Signal strength in dB.
member.returns: String: "No Signal", "Very Low", "Low", "Good", "Very Good", "Excellent", or "Not a wireless adapter".

member.summary: The StrengthToString static conversion function allows a previously stored signal strength enumeration value to be converted into its string representation.
member.param: One of the SignalStrength enumeration values.
member.returns: String: "No Signal", "Very Low", "Low", "Good", "Very Good", "Excellent", or "Not a wireless adapter".

member.summary: Converts strength to string representing relative strength ("Good", "Low", etc.)

member.summary: The Decibels property returns the signal strength in dB.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface
member.summary:
Provides configuration and statistical information for a network interface.
New in v1.3

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface.GetAllNetworkInterfaces
member.summary: Returns objects that describe the network interfaces on the local computer.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface.GetIPInterfaceProperties
member.summary: Returns an object that describes the configuration of this network interface.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NDIS_802_11_CONFIGURATION_FH.DwellTime
member.summary: Amount of time dwelling in each frequency (in kusec).

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NDIS_802_11_BSSID_LIST
member.summary: This class represents the data returned by the OID_802_11_BSSID_LIST query to an RF Ethernet adapter. It is just used during parsing of the returned data and really should not persist.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthAddon
member.summary: Abstract class representing a 'different' method of finding the signal strength for a network adapter. You might need to provide a subclass of this class when your code runs on Windows CE 3.0 or earlier or when the signal strength is not retrievable via the Windows CE.NET NDISUIO driver in the standard 802.11 manner.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthAddon.RFSignalStrengthDB(OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter)
member.summary: Abstract method. Your subclass of StrengthAddon must implement this method and do whatever is needed to get the RF signal strength in dB from the indicated adapter. Return 0 if the adapter is not an RF adapter or there is an error.
member.param: Instance of Adapter class for which signal strength is to be returned
member.returns: int signal strength in dB or zero for error

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.StrengthAddon.RFSSID(OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter)
member.summary: Abstract method. Your subclass of StrengthAddon must implement this method and do whatever is needed to get the current SSID from the indicated adapter. Return null if the adapter is not an RF adapter, if it is not presently associated, or there is an error.
member.param: Instance of Adapter class for which SSID is to be returned
member.returns: String SSID string or null for error or unassociated

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue
member.summary: The PointToPointMsgQueue class wraps the Windows CE point-to- point message queue object type. It is used primarily for interprocess communication between device drivers, who send notifications of change of status, etc. and applications, who might display status information or take action when the status changes.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags)
member.summary: Create a new point-to-point message queue object.
member.param: Indicates the name of a named queue. Set to null to create an unnamed queue.
Indicates the length of the queue in messages.
Indicates the maximum size of each message in the queue.
Set to true if messages will be read from the queue, false if messages will be written to the queue. A read/write queue cannot be created.
Flags indicating how the queue will operate.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.Finalize
member.summary: The queue is closed.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.Close
member.summary: Closes the message queue.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.ReadMsgQueue(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32,OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags@)
member.summary: Read the next item from the message queue.
member.param: Caller-allocated byte array for the data.
Number of bytes in the caller-allocated buffer.
Return value indicating number of bytes actually read and stored in the buffer.
Time-out value in ms for the read. If no messages arrive before the time-out occurs, the number of bytes read will be zero.
Will be set to AlertMsg if the message was written to the queue with that flag set. Zero, otherwise.
member.returns: True is returned on a successful read; false otherwise.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.WriteMsgQueue(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags)
member.summary: Write a new item to the message queue.
member.param: Caller-allocated byte array for the data.
Number of bytes in the caller-allocated buffer.
Time-out value in ms for the read. If no messages arrive before the time-out occurs, the number of bytes read will be zero.
Can be set to AlertMsg, if an 'alert message' is to be posted to the queue. Otherwise, set to zero.
member.returns: True is returned on a successful write; false otherwise.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.Wait(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for the queue to be signaled, indicating, for a read queue, that items are in the queue or, for a write queue, that the queue is not full and can be written.
member.param: Time to wait in ms. Set to -1 for infinite wait.
member.returns: True if the queue is signaled; false if the time-out passed before the queue was ready.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.Handle
member.summary: Access the raw message queue handle.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.CreatedNew
member.summary: Access indicator of whether the queue was created new during construction (true) or if an existing queue was connected (false).

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueue.Valid
member.summary: Return indicator of valid queue connection.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags
member.summary: The PointToPointMsgQueueFlags enumeration gives the values which can be passed in the flags parameter when creating a PointToPointMsgQueue instance.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags.NoPrecommit
member.summary: Set when the length of the message queue is not limited at creation time. Set maxMessages to zero, also, when setting this flag.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags.AllowBroken
member.summary: Set to allow sending and receiving, even when there is no complete connection between a writer and one or more readers.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.PointToPointMsgQueueFlags.AlertMsg
member.summary: Set during a read/write operation to indicate an 'alert message' in the queue.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter
member.summary: Class representing a single instance of a network adapter, which might include PCMCIA cards, USB network cards, built-in Ethernet chips, etc.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.StrengthFetcher
member.summary: Field, if set, is used, if the NDISUIO method fails, to get the RF signal strength. You might use this on an OS earlier than 4.0, when NDISUIO became available. You'd usually create your own subclass of StrengthAddon, then assign an instance of that subclass to this property, then ask for the signal strength.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.BindAdapter
member.summary: Method called on unbound adapter (maybe when handling changing *both* the IP/subnet/gateway *and* the wireless settings). This method notifies NDIS to bind the adapter to all protocols indicated in the registry, in effect causing the current registry settings to be applied rather than those which the adapter is currently using. Since we are binding, not *re*-binding the protocols, we are implying that the adapter is not currently bound to anything. When making this call, we must refresh any adapter list that we might have, to retrieve the current state of all adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.RebindAdapter
member.summary: Method called after making some changes to the current IP address, subnet mask, etc. This method notifies NDIS to rebind the adapter to all protocols, in effect causing the current registry settings to be applied rather than those which the current configuration represents. Once you have rebound an adapter, to get its new configuration, you must regenerate the list of adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.UnbindAdapter
member.summary: Method called to unbind a given adapter. You might perform this operation before attempting to change *both* the protocol configuration of an adapter (IP, subnet, gateway), *and* the wireless configuration of the same adapter (WEP, SSID, etc.) To do that, first unbind the adapter, then change the settings, then bind the adapter (UnbindAdapter(), make changes, BindAdapter()). Once you have bound/unbound an adapter, to get its new configuration, you must regenerate the list of adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.ToString
member.summary: Converts the Adapter to a string representation. We use the adapter's name for this.
member.returns: string representing the adapter

member.summary: Modifies wireless settings associated with a given interface and AP
member.param: Target SSID to connect
Is infrastructure
WEP key
member.returns: True if successful

member.summary: Modifies wireless settings associated with a given interface and AP
member.param: Target SSID to connect
Is infrastructure
binary wep key - 5 or 13 bytes
member.returns: true if succeeded

member.summary: Sets wireless settings associated with a given interface and AP. This version of the method is designed for the case where *all* of the options are going to be set, where no initial configuration exists at all.
member.param: Target SSID to connect
Is infrastructure
wep key string representing hex string (each two characters are converted to a single byte)
Authentication mode for the connection
member.returns: true if succeeded

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.Adapter.SetWirelessSettingsEx(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Byte[],OpenNETCF.Net.AuthenticationMode)
member.summary: Sets wireless settings associated with a given interface and AP. This version of the method is designed for the case where *all* of the options are going to be set, where no initial configuration exists at all.
member.param: Target SSID to connect
Is infrastructure
binary wep key - 5 or 13 bytes
Authentication mode for the connection
member.returns: true if succeeded

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.WZC_WLAN_CONFIG_LIST
member.summary: This class represents the data returned by the WZCQueryInterface() call to WZC. There are several values in the INTF_ENTRY struct returned by that query, including a couple of SSID lists (those SSID values currently 'audible' to the adapter and the preferred list). This type is how those lists are returned.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPointCollection
member.summary: Class that represents a collection of the SSID values that a given network adapter can hear over the airwaves. For each SSID, you can get the signal strength and random other information.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPointCollection.Refresh
member.summary: Refresh the list of SSID values, asking the adapter to scan for new ones, also.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPointCollection.FindBySSID(System.String)
member.summary: Find a given access point in the collection by looking for a matching SSID value.

member.summary: Gets the address of the host that sends the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo reply.

member.summary: Gets the buffer of data received in an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo reply message.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingReply.RoundTripTime
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds taken to send an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo request and receive the corresponding ICMP echo reply message.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.PingReply.Status
member.summary: Gets the status of an attempt to send an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo request and receive the corresponding ICMP echo reply message.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.AdapterCollection
member.summary: Class that represents a collection of network adapters connected to the Windows CE device. Each adapter can be queried for information such as the signal strength (RF only), the activity state, etc.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint
member.summary: The SSID class represents a single SSID value which an adapter might be receiving data from. It can be queried for SSID-specific information for the associated adapter such as signal strength.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.ToString
member.summary: Return the name of the AccessPoint
member.returns: string name of the access point

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.Name
member.summary: The SSID name string.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.MacAddress
member.summary: The hardware address for the network adapter.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.Privacy
member.summary: The privacy mask for the adapter.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.SignalStrengthInDecibels
member.summary: Returns the strength of the RF Ethernet signal being received by the adapter for the SSID, in dB.
member.returns: integer strength in dB; zero, if adapter is not an RF adapter or an error occurred

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.SignalStrength
member.summary: Returns the strength of the RF Ethernet signal being received by the adapter for the SSID, in dB.
member.returns: SignalStrength instance containing the strength

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.SupportedRates
member.summary: Returns the list of supported signaling rates for the adapter. Each value indicates a single rate.
member.returns: array of bytes, each of which represents a rate. The units are 0.5Mbps. Rates that belong to the 'basic rate set' have their high bits set to 1 (they are OR-ed with 0x80). Rates which are not in the basic rate set, have this bit clear. So, a value of 0x96, after clearing the high bit, is 0x16 or 22d. Multiplying by 0.5Mbps gives a rate of 11Mbps. Since the high bit was set, this rate is in the basic rate set.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.NetworkTypeInUse
member.summary: Returns the current type of network in use in the form of an element of the Ndis80211NetworkType enumeration.
member.returns: Ndis80211NetworkType network type

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.AccessPoint.InfrastructureMode
member.summary: Returns the current infrastructure in use by the adapter.
member.returns: Ndis80211NetworkInfrastructure type
